2-Column Masonry Layout

Spec

Cards are arranged into two columns of equal height. Consistent spacing is maintained between the cards, but the cards themselves may grow in height to fit. Keyboard users traverse the cards using the tab key, progressing from left-to-right, top-to-bottom.

Challenge

The challenge is maintaining equal height columns. CSS masonry layout support is still experimental and extremely limited. CSS multicolumn layout would place cards into columns and the focus order would be top-to-bottom, left-to-right instead of the intuitive order. With CSS flexbox, the focus order could get muddled if a card in one column is much bigger than one in the other column.

Strategy

Starting with a CSS grid layout of 2 equal-width columns ensures that the focus order is maintained even if JavaScript is not enabled.

Then, using JavaScript, calculate the heights of the cards in each column. For the shorter column, evenly distribute the difference in height relative to the other column among the cards. Render the result with fixed heights and absolute positioning. The total height must be applied to the container since its children are all absolutely positioned. Recalculate upon throttled window resize.

Result

Google Year in Search 2021

Google's annual exploration of search trends from the year. (Live Site)

Accessible Responsive Content Reveal

Spec

Cards are staggered down the page. When a card is clicked, its detailed view is revealed, with more information and shareable links. On small screens, the detailed view shows as a modal dialog. On wide screens, the detailed view opens to the left of the main content, and the main content remains interactive and independently scrollable while the detailed view is open.

Challenge

The modal dialog is straightforward, but its relationship to the view that opens to the left side and the mechanism for transitioning between the two in a responsive manner are unclear.

Strategy

The detailed view that opens on the left side should be considered a non-modal dialog, since it presents an additional interactive context without inhibiting interaction with the original context. As such, converting between the two requires flipping the aria-modal="true|false" state of the dialog and the inert="true|false" state of the main content.

Result

A celebration of LGBTQ communities around the world. (Live Site)

Responsive Editorial Layouts

Spec

Content is featured in magazine/editorial style, with roomy white space, asymmetrical layouts, and a focus on imagery. The dynamism of the editorial style is maintained on small and large screens.

Challenge

Some components, or pairs of components, need to fit on screen to fill up as much space as possible without scrolling.

Strategy

Determine the current available space in JavaScript by taking the viewport height and subtracting the chrome frame of the browser, along with the header, footer, and share bar and provide it in CSS as a variable/custom property.

Result

LiveSchool app

LiveSchool is an app and website that helps educators manage student behavior by awarding behavior points and allowing students to redeem their points for rewards. (Live Site)

Realtime Event System

The LiveSchool app tracks student behavior in realtime using Firebase, allowing educators to award points to students and view their behavior history. If a teacher is logged in from multiple devices, then the app synchronizes data instantly across all devices. The use case was that a teacher would award points on their phone and the points would increment or decrement on a projected laptop screen.

My role was to key off of Firebase events and update the Vue interface accordingly. The data was stored in Vuex, which would be updated with mutations. The state changes would trigger the interface to update.

Users came to expect that all aspects of the app experience would update instantaneously across devices, including their settings. For example, if a teacher changed the relative size of the student cards, then the change would be reflected on other devices. This required throttling the events to prevent the app from becoming sluggish, while still maintaining smooth animations. Moreover, the number of realtime events made the app far more complex than it appeared on the surface, but the overall experience was highly useful to educators.

Responsive App Interface

Spec

The LiveSchool app is responsive and adaptable, ensuring a seamless user experience that doesn't require learning multiple interfaces when switching between devices.

Challenge

The app must deliver a uniform experience across devices, from smartphones to projected laptop screens. It showcases very long or very short student names, along with their behavior points; and features like student selection and viewing behavior history. Interface components must be performant and user-friendly, especially on touch devices.

Strategy

Flexbox wrapping efficiently organizes elements, such as student lists, adapting to varied screen widths. Text-overflow elision prevents text, like long student names, from overflowing by truncating it with an ellipsis ('...'). Breakpoints, applied selectively, adjust the design at specific screen dimensions for optimal viewing and, in rare cases, JavaScript is used to assess available display space.

Long, scrollable lists of students are virtualized, ensuring the app runs smoothly, especially on older devices or slower networks.

Result

Apple Online Store

The Apple.com Store pages include the buy flow, cart, and checkout. (Live Site)

CSS Architecture and Migration to SCSS

I spearheaded a significant re-architecture of the CSS codebase for the Apple Online Store. I was entrusted with the lead role for the three distinct phases of the project:

  1. Leading the core team, conducting research, sharing knowledge, creating prototypes, and making pivotal decisions.
  2. Architecting the build system, envisioning the entire pipeline, managing offshore work, and ensuring seamless integration into our main codebase.
  3. Creating a style guide and linter, and supporting project teams with adoption.

As a team, we researched CSS patterns and preprocessing/postprocessing frameworks. The ultimate decision to adopt SCSS was strategic, aligning with the Marketing department's tools and facilitating code sharing. This emphasized the crucial nature of UI parity between Marketing and Online Store sections of the website, and positioned us as partners who could contribute to the ecosystem.

Apple Watch Launch

For the September 2014 launch of the iPhone 6 and the new Apple Watch, I worked under secrecy constraints, received security training, and was placed in a sequestered office alongside Marketing team designers, engineers, and PMs. I prototyped and delivered the final version of what would become the public's first glimpse at the Apple Watch.
